title.value: Model-based graph reinforcement learning for inductive traffic signal control
title.justification: The title is extracted directly from the provided paper excerpt.
title.quote: Model-based graph reinforcement learning for inductive traffic signal control

extractions.description: This paper introduces MuJAM, a model-based reinforcement learning method using graph neural networks for adaptive traffic signal control that enables scalable, transferable, and constraint-agnostic control policies.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments, evaluations, and comparisons of the proposed MuJAM method with different baselines which indicates empirical research.
type.quote: We compare the performence of instantiations of MuJAM and several baselines on both small synthetic road networks and the road network of Manhattan.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on model-based reinforcement learning for traffic signal control.
name.quote: Model-based RL (MBRL), which explicitly models the dynamics of the environment tend to both outperform model-free RL (MFRL) in complex planning tasks and enable better sample efficiency.

name.justification: The paper utilizes graph convolutional networks (GCNs) for modeling traffic dynamics and traffic signal control.
name.quote: Instead of using loop sensor information and resorting to manual and arbitrary aggregations, flexibility in the computational graph offered by graph convolutional networks (GCNs) enables the exploitation of available data at its finest level of granularity.

name.justification: The specific application focus of the paper is on adaptive traffic signal control using reinforcement learning techniques.
name.quote: Adaptive traffic signal control, Zero-shot transfer, Large-scale application

name.justification: The paper discusses the use of multi-agent systems in the coordination of traffic signal control across different intersections.
name.quote: Multi-Agent RL (MARL) in particular, promises scalability of RL approaches by dividing control among intersections...

name.justification: The primary model proposed in the paper is called MuJAM.
name.quote: We introduce a new model-based method, MuJAM, which, on top of enabling explicit coordination at scale for the first time, pushes generalization further by allowing a generalization to the controllersâ€™ constraints.

is_contributed.justification: MuJAM is introduced as a new model in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

is_executed.justification: The experiments described in the paper involve execution of the MuJAM model.
is_executed.quote: We compare the performence [sic] of instantiations of MuJAM and several baselines on both small synthetic road networks and the road network of Manhattan.

is_compared.justification: MuJAM is compared numerically against other models and baselines in the paper's experiments.
is_compared.quote: We compare the performence [sic] of instantiations of MuJAM and several baselines on both small synthetic road networks and the road network of Manhattan.

referenced_paper_title.justification: MuJAM is a novel contribution of this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

name.justification: MuZero serves as a foundational model on which MuJAM is built.
name.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

is_contributed.justification: MuZero is an established model that is utilized within the paper, not contributed.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not describe the execution of MuZero itself but rather its integration into MuJAM.
is_executed.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

is_compared.justification: MuZero itself is not compared directly, it is used as a part of MuJAM which is compared.
is_compared.quote: We introduce joint action modeling with MuZero, MuJAM, a new family of MBRL approaches for RL-ATSC which models dynamics of the ATSC environment at the lane level using a latent space.

referenced_paper_title.value: Mastering Atari, Go, Chess and Shogi by Planning with a Learned Model
referenced_paper_title.justification: MuZero is referenced in the context of its original paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We adapt recent MBRL approaches to enable more efficient exploration which translates into better data efficiency as we gather more relevant signal with fewer interactions with the environment.

name.justification: IG-RL is another model used for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: IG-RL: This is the only learnt baseline for which zero-shot transfer to new road architectures and traffic distributions is achievable.

is_contributed.justification: IG-RL is used as a baseline, not a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: IG-RL: This is the only learnt baseline for which zero-shot transfer to new road architectures and traffic distributions is achievable.

is_executed.justification: The IG-RL model is executed and its performance is evaluated in the paper.
is_executed.quote: IG-RL: This is the only learnt baseline for which zero-shot transfer to new road architectures and traffic distributions is achievable.

is_compared.justification: Numerical comparisons are made between IG-RL and other models including MuJAM.
is_compared.quote: IG-RL: This is the only learnt baseline for which zero-shot transfer to new road architectures and traffic distributions is achievable.

referenced_paper_title.value: IG-RL: Inductive Graph Reinforcement Learning for Massively-Scalable Traffic Signal Control
referenced_paper_title.justification: The IG-RL model is clearly referenced as being used from its original paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: IG-RL: This is the only learnt baseline for which zero-shot transfer to new road architectures and traffic distributions is achievable.
